children.text: Select all statements that correctly describe working with Development Spaces in SAP Business Application Studio for SAP HANA Cloud modeling.

Developers use SAP Business Application Studio to model for SAP HANA Cloud within personal Development Spaces configured with needed tools. Certain operational limits and maintenance rules apply to these spaces.
Each developer works in one or more personal Development Spaces within SAP Business Application Studio.
The text states that each developer has their own environment made up of one or more Development Spaces.
For SAP HANA Cloud modeling, the SAP HANA Calculation View Editor extension must be included when creating a Development Space.
The text explicitly calls this extension essential for modeling in SAP HANA Cloud.
Multiple Development Spaces can run simultaneously for a single developer to parallelize tasks.
The text says only one Development Space can be running at one time; you must stop one to start another.
Development Spaces are the same as Cloud Foundry spaces and share the same lifecycle controls.
The text warns not to confuse Development Spaces with Cloud Foundry spaces, implying they are different.
After creation, you can rename a Development Space and change its application kind at any time.
The text states that when a Development Space is created, its name and kind of application cannot be changed.
Differentiate Development Spaces from other platform constructs like Cloud Foundry spaces.
Check operational constraints: what can run concurrently and what can be changed after creation.
Think PEO: Personal spaces, Essential extension, One running at a time.

A and B reflect the personal, tool-configured nature of Development Spaces and the essential HANA Calculation View Editor. C contradicts the one-running-at-a-time rule. D ignores the explicit caution against equating them with Cloud Foundry spaces. E conflicts with the immutability of name and application kind after creation.
Which statements in the text describe limits on running or modifying Development Spaces?
A developer sets up a new Development Space with the HANA Calculation View Editor, stops an existing space, and starts the new one to work on modeling.
In SAP Business Application Studio, which choice is essential when setting up a development space specifically for modeling in SAP HANA Cloud?
Developers work in personal development spaces and select extensions based on their tasks. Certain tools are crucial for modeling activities in SAP HANA Cloud.
Include the SAP HANA Calculation View Editor extension in the development space.
The text states this extension is essential for modeling in SAP HANA Cloud.
Rename the development space to match the project folder name.
The name of a development space cannot be changed after creation.
Run multiple development spaces simultaneously to separate tools.
Only one development space can be running at a time; you must stop one to start another.
Configure Cloud Foundry spaces inside the development space wizard.
The text warns not to confuse development spaces with Cloud Foundry spaces; this setup is not described here.
Change the kind of application of the space after creation to add modeling features.
The kind of application cannot be changed once the development space is created.
Focus on what is described as essential for modeling in SAP HANA Cloud.
Eliminate options that refer to renaming or changing the space after creation.
Modeling needs the Modeler: pick the Calculation View Editor.

Modeling in SAP HANA Cloud requires the SAP HANA Calculation View Editor extension in the development space; other options contradict constraints on naming, running, or confusing with Cloud Foundry spaces.
What other extensions might you add for broader development needs beyond modeling?
When creating a space for HANA modeling, select the HANA Calculation View Editor so you can build calculation views.
Statement: In SAP Business Application Studio, only one Development Space can be running at a time for a user.
The unit discusses Business Application Studio, creating and managing Development Spaces, required extensions for SAP HANA Cloud modeling, and operational constraints when switching between spaces.
True
False
Recall what must happen before you can swap to a different Development Space.
Think about runtime limits mentioned when managing multiple spaces.
One at a time: stop one space to start another.
The text specifies that only one Development Space can be running at a time; to switch, you must stop the currently running space first.
How would the statement change if multiple spaces could run simultaneously?
A developer stops Space A before starting Space B to continue modeling tasks.
Select all statements that correctly describe development spaces and tooling in SAP Business Application Studio for SAP HANA Cloud modeling.
This unit covers SAP Business Application Studio (BAS), creating development spaces, required extensions for modeling, workspace layout, and basic project setup actions.
Each developer works in one or more development spaces that make up their BAS environment.
The text states that each developer has their own environment made up of one or more Development Spaces.
For SAP HANA Cloud modeling, the SAP HANA Calculation View Editor extension must be included in the development space.
It is described as essential for modeling in SAP HANA Cloud.
A development space can be renamed and its application kind changed after creation.
The text says the name and kind of application cannot be changed after creation.
Multiple development spaces can run simultaneously for a single developer.
Only one development space can be running at a time; you must stop one to start another.
Development spaces in BAS are the same as Cloud Foundry spaces and can be used interchangeably.
The text warns not to confuse development spaces with Cloud Foundry spaces.
Identify statements that reflect how BAS structures a developer’s environment.
Consider the constraints on running, naming, and configuring development spaces mentioned in the lesson.
Think SPACE: Single running, Personal areas, Add essential extension, Cannot rename, End confusion with CF.

A and B align with the description of BAS environments and required tooling for HANA modeling. C, D, and E contradict constraints and clarifications provided: no renaming or changing kind after creation, only one space runs at a time, and CF spaces are distinct.
Which parts of the description distinguish BAS development spaces from Cloud Foundry spaces?
When starting a HANA modeling project, create a development space and include the Calculation View Editor; stop any running space before starting another.
In SAP Business Application Studio, which action is essential when setting up a development space specifically for modeling in SAP HANA Cloud?
Developers work in isolated development spaces in SAP Business Application Studio. These spaces are configured with selected tools (extensions) and only one development space can run at a time.
Include the SAP HANA Calculation View Editor extension in the development space.
The text states this extension is essential for modeling in SAP HANA Cloud.
Rename the development space to reflect the project’s current sprint.
The name cannot be changed after creation, per the text.
Run multiple development spaces simultaneously to parallelize tasks.
Only one development space can be running at a time, according to the text.
Configure Cloud Foundry spaces within the development space setup wizard.
The text warns not to confuse development spaces with Cloud Foundry spaces; this is not part of setup.
Change the kind of application of the development space after creation to add modeling support.
The kind of application cannot be changed once the space is created.
Focus on what the text labels as essential for HANA Cloud modeling.
Eliminate options that involve renaming or changing the kind after creation.
Essential for modeling = include the modeling editor.
For modeling in SAP HANA Cloud, the development space must include the SAP HANA Calculation View Editor extension; other options contradict the stated constraints or scope.
Which other extensions might you add without changing the development space’s name or kind?
When creating a new space for HANA modeling, select the SAP HANA Calculation View Editor in the extensions list before launching the space.
The statement below is accurate according to the text.
Statement: In SAP Business Application Studio, a development space’s name and kind of application cannot be changed after creation.
The unit introduces SAP Business Application Studio (BAS), development spaces, required extensions for SAP HANA Cloud modeling, and operational considerations when creating and managing spaces.
True
False
Focus on what can and cannot be modified after a space is created.
Distinguish between changing core properties versus adding optional elements later.
Name and kind are set in stone; options can be added on.
The text specifies that once a Development Space is created, its name and kind of application cannot be changed.
If core properties are fixed, what aspects of a development space remain adjustable later?
A developer creates a space for HANA modeling and later adds an extension, but the original space name and type stay the same.
Which actions align with importing or sharing development content in SAP Business Application Studio as described?
The context discusses importing existing projects into a BAS workspace and using Git for sharing source code among developers working in parallel.
Import a project from a .zip or .tar archive into your BAS workspace.
The text states you can import a project into BAS from a .zip or .tar archive.
Use Git to manage source code and collaborate with other developers.
The text explains Git is used to manage source code and support collaboration/parallel work.
Share development content in SAP HANA Cloud projects primarily via manual file exports rather than Git.
The text identifies Git as the preferred method for sharing development content.
Rely on Web IDE instead of BAS when importing existing projects.
The context centers on importing projects in BAS, not switching to Web IDE.
Avoid using version control when multiple developers work in parallel.
The text highlights Git for collaboration and parallel work, not avoiding version control.
Identify which options explicitly match import mechanisms mentioned.
Look for statements consistent with Git as the preferred sharing method.
Think: Zip/Tar to get in; Git to share out.

Importing can be done from .zip or .tar archives into BAS, and Git is the preferred tool for sharing and collaborative source control. Options suggesting alternatives that contradict these points are incorrect.
Where in the text is the preferred sharing method stated?
What file formats are mentioned for importing projects into BAS?
A developer imports a .zip project into BAS, then uses Git to push changes for teammates to pull.
In SAP Business Application Studio, which method aligns with the recommended approach for sharing development content in an SAP HANA Cloud project?

The context mentions importing existing projects into SAP Business Application Studio and that a preferred method exists for sharing development content in SAP HANA Cloud projects to support collaboration and parallel work.
Use Git to manage and share source code
The text states Git is the preferred method for sharing development content and managing source code for collaboration.
Email project files to teammates
Email-based sharing is not described as the preferred method in the text.
Rely exclusively on local file copies
Local copies are not indicated as a collaborative sharing method in the text.
Upload archives to a generic file server
The text highlights Git, not generic file servers, as the preferred sharing approach.
Share via Web IDE’s built-in exporter
Web IDE is mentioned but not as the preferred method for sharing in this context.
Focus on the tool noted as preferred for collaboration and parallel work.
Distinguish between ad-hoc file transfer and source-controlled sharing.
Think: Git for group work—preferred for parallel development.
Git is explicitly identified as the preferred way to share and manage source code for collaborative development in SAP HANA Cloud projects.
How does using Git support parallel development compared to manual file sharing?
A team clones a repository into BAS workspaces to collaborate on the same HANA project.
Git is presented as the preferred method for sharing development content in an SAP HANA Cloud project.
The context discusses importing projects into SAP Business Application Studio and mentions approaches to share and manage development content in SAP HANA Cloud projects.
True
False
Look for wording that signals preference or recommendation for a sharing method.
Focus on the sentence describing how development content is shared among developers.
Preferred for sharing in HANA Cloud? Think Git as the go-to collaboration tool.
The text states that Git is the preferred method for sharing development content in an SAP HANA Cloud project.
If this statement were false, what alternative sharing method would the text have needed to prefer?
Developers collaborate by pushing and pulling project changes via Git repositories.
Which statements about importing projects and using Git in SAP Business Application Studio are supported by the context? Select all that apply.
The lesson discusses importing existing projects into a BAS workspace and using Git for sharing development content and collaborating in SAP HANA Cloud projects.
You can import a project into BAS from a .zip or .tar archive.
The context explicitly mentions importing a project from a .zip or .tar archive.
Git is the preferred method for sharing development content in SAP HANA Cloud projects.
The context states that Git is the preferred method for sharing development content.
Projects can only be started from templates; importing archives is not supported.
This contradicts the stated ability to import from .zip or .tar archives.
Git is primarily used for deployment of SAP HANA artifacts rather than source control.
The context frames Git as source code management and collaboration, not primarily deployment.
BAS only supports cloning from Git and does not offer an Import option.
The context lists both Clone from Git and Import as available options.
Look for mentions of supported import mechanisms in the context.
Identify how Git is characterized in the development workflow described.
Think IG: Import via archives, Git for sharing.

The text supports importing from .zip/.tar archives and identifies Git as the preferred method for sharing and collaborating on source code. Claims that exclude Import or mischaracterize Git are not supported.
Where does the context describe Import and Clone from Git, and how does it define Git’s role?
A developer downloads a .zip project and imports it into BAS; teammates share updates via Git to collaborate in parallel.
In SAP Business Application Studio, which method aligns with the preferred approach for sharing development content in an SAP HANA Cloud project?

The lesson discusses importing projects into SAP Business Application Studio and highlights a preferred method for sharing development content in SAP HANA Cloud projects to enable collaboration and parallel work.
Use Git for source control and collaboration.
The context states Git is the preferred method for sharing development content and managing collaborative source code work.
Exchange .zip or .tar archives via email only.
Archives are mentioned for importing a project, not as the preferred sharing method for collaboration.
Rely on Database Explorer exports for team code sharing.
Database Explorer is referenced as a tool but not as the preferred mechanism for sharing development content.
Use Web IDE workspaces for all collaboration.
Web IDE is listed among tools, but the preferred sharing method highlighted is Git.
Share code through manual file copies in the Explorer view.
Explorer can list files and folders, but manual copying is not identified as the preferred collaborative approach.
Recall which tool the text calls the preferred method for sharing development content.
Differentiate between importing from archives and ongoing collaborative sharing.
Preferred sharing = Git: collaborate, branch, merge.
Git is explicitly identified as the preferred method for sharing development content and managing collaborative, parallel work in SAP HANA Cloud projects.
How does using Git improve parallel development compared to exchanging archives?
A team clones a repository into BAS, creates branches, and merges changes via Git to share work.
Git is described as the preferred method for sharing development content in an SAP HANA Cloud project.
The context discusses importing existing projects into SAP Business Application Studio and highlights approaches to share development content among collaborators in SAP HANA Cloud projects.
True
False
Focus on what the text calls the preferred method for sharing content.
Look for statements about collaboration and managing source code.
Preferred method = the tool emphasized for collaboration and sharing.
The text explicitly states that Git is the preferred method for sharing development content in an SAP HANA Cloud project.
If the statement were false, what alternative tool would the text have needed to name as preferred?
Developers push and pull code via Git to collaborate on an SAP HANA Cloud project.
Select all statements that align with the unit’s scope and properties of calculation views.

This unit covers creating different types of calculation views with the graphical editor, understanding supported sources, and how results are consumed. Consider creation scope, read/write behavior, and consumption patterns.
You can create dimension, cube, and time-based dimension calculation views using the graphical calculation view editor.
The unit objective explicitly includes creating dimension, cube, and time-based dimension calculation views using the graphical editor.
Calculation views are read-only and cannot change data in SAP HANA Cloud.
The context states calculation views are read only and cannot change data.
Analytical applications must route all queries through an application server and cannot query calculation views directly.
The text says analytical applications can bypass the application server and directly query calculation views.
Calculation views are primarily designed for writing aggregated results back into database tables.
Contradicted by the statement that calculation views are read-only and cannot change data.
ABAP systems cannot consume calculation views.
The context notes it is possible to consume a calculation view from ABAP.
Identify which objectives explicitly mention types of calculation views and the editor used.
Check statements about read/write behavior and how applications access views.
Think D-C-T: Dimension, Cube, Time; and R for Read-only.

A and B match the stated objectives and properties: creation of dimension/cube/time-based views via the graphical editor and read-only behavior. C and D conflict with direct-access and read-only notes. E contradicts the note that ABAP can consume calculation views.
From the context, list where calculation views can be consumed and whether they support data modification.
An analytical dashboard queries a cube calculation view directly in SAP HANA Cloud without routing through the application server and does not perform any data writes.
Which statement best reflects the role of calculation views in SAP HANA Cloud as described for this unit?

The unit covers creating dimension, cube, and time-based calculation views using the graphical editor, understanding supported sources, checking outputs, and recognizing that analytical applications can directly query calculation views.
They are read-only models that analytical applications can query directly to compute results on-the-fly.
The context states calculation views are read-only and can be directly queried by analytical applications with on-the-fly calculation.
They primarily serve to write aggregated results back into SAP HANA Cloud tables.
The text explicitly says calculation views are read-only and cannot change data.
They can only be consumed through an application server layer and not directly by applications.
The text notes analytical apps can bypass the application server and directly query calculation views.
They replace hierarchies, which are not defined within calculation views.
The context says you can define hierarchies in calculation views; they are not replacements.
They are limited to dimension views and do not support cubes or time-based structures.
The unit includes creating dimension, cube, and time-based dimension calculation views.
Recall whether the unit mentions writing back to tables from calculation views.
Think about how analytical applications access data models according to the text.
ROR: Read-Only and Reachable—calculation views are read-only yet directly reachable by analytics.
The unit emphasizes that calculation views are read-only models that can be directly queried by analytical applications, with data computed on-the-fly in SAP HANA Cloud.
How does direct querying of calculation views benefit analytical applications?
An ABAP application can consume a calculation view directly to retrieve calculated results without persisting them.
Calculation views in SAP HANA Cloud are read-only objects and cannot modify underlying database data.
This unit covers creating dimension, cube, and time-based calculation views using the graphical editor, supported data sources, and how analytical applications consume these views.
True
False
Consider how analytical applications interact with views versus tables.
Recall whether the unit mentions writing data through calculation views.
Views ‘view’ data—think read, not write.
The text states that calculation views are read only and cannot change data in the SAP HANA Cloud database.
If the statement were false, what capability would calculation views need that the unit explicitly denies?
An analytical app queries a cube view to compute metrics without issuing any data modifications.
Select all statements that are supported by the unit’s overview of calculation views.

The unit covers modeling terminology, creating dimension, cube, and time-based calculation views with the graphical editor, supported sources, checking outputs, and the role of hierarchies and application access patterns.
You can create dimension, cube, and time-based dimension calculation views using the graphical calculation view editor.
The unit explicitly lists creating dimension, cube, and time-based dimension views with the graphical editor.
Calculation views are read-only and do not change data in SAP HANA Cloud.
The text states calculation views are read only and cannot change data.
Analytical applications must route all queries through the application server before accessing calculation views.
The text says analytical applications can bypass the application server and directly query calculation views.
Hierarchies cannot be defined in calculation views; they must be maintained only in source tables.
The text notes you can define one or more hierarchies in calculation views.
ABAP cannot consume calculation views because they are limited to database-native tools.
The text provides ABAP as an example that can consume a calculation view.
Identify which statements match the unit’s explicit capabilities list.
Watch for wording about read vs. write behavior and access paths.
Think D-C-T: Dimension, Cube, Time — created graphically and queried read-only.

A and B align with the unit: it teaches creating dimension, cube, and time-based views with the graphical editor, and emphasizes calculation views are read-only. C contradicts the direct-query note. D conflicts with the ability to define hierarchies in calculation views. E is refuted by the ABAP consumption example.
How do read-only semantics influence validation steps when checking calculation view outputs?
An analytical app performs drill-down on a hierarchy defined in a calculation view and queries it directly without modifying any data.
Which statement best reflects the role of calculation views in SAP HANA Cloud as described for this unit?

This unit covers creating dimension, cube, and time-based calculation views using the graphical editor, checking outputs, supported sources, and understanding read-only usage patterns and hierarchies.
They are read-only models that can be queried directly by analytical applications to compute results on-the-fly in-memory.
The text states calculation views are read only and analytical apps can directly query them where data is calculated on-the-fly in the in-memory database.
They primarily serve to write aggregated results back into SAP HANA Cloud tables.
Contradicted by the text: calculation views are read only and cannot change data.
They are only accessible through an application server layer and cannot be consumed directly.
The text explains analytical applications can bypass the application server and directly query calculation views.
They are limited to hierarchy definitions and cannot model cubes or dimensions.
The unit explicitly covers creating dimension, cube, and time-based calculation views; hierarchies are just one feature.
They must be used by ABAP applications exclusively and are unsuitable for other consumers.
The text gives ABAP as an example of a possible consumer, not an exclusive requirement.
Recall whether calculation views can change data or are read-only.
Consider how analytical applications interact with calculation views per the unit.
Think ROC: Read-only, On-the-fly, Consumed directly.
Calculation views in this unit are positioned as read-only, directly consumable models for analytical queries, with computations performed on-the-fly in the in-memory database.
How does direct querying of calculation views influence application architecture choices?
An analytic dashboard calls a cube calculation view directly to retrieve aggregated sales without persisting new tables.
Calculation views in SAP HANA Cloud are read-only objects and cannot directly modify data in database tables.

This unit covers creating dimension, cube, and time-based calculation views with the graphical editor, understanding supported data sources, checking outputs, and how hierarchies support drill-down navigation.
True
False
Consider whether analytical models typically update data or just query and compute results.
Recall the unit’s note about applications querying views directly for on-the-fly calculations.
Think: CV = Calculate & View, not Change & Write.
The unit states calculation views are read only and cannot change data in the SAP HANA Cloud database.
If the statement were false, what capabilities would calculation views need to have?
An analytical app queries a cube calculation view to compute metrics without issuing any data updates.
Select ALL statements that correctly describe dimension calculation views and their usage.
Dimension calculation views focus on master data exposure and are commonly reused across analytical models. Consider their behavior with attributes and how they relate to cube calculation views.
They expose master data and can combine multiple sources, filters, calculated attributes, and hierarchies.
The text states that a dimension calculation view exposes master data, can combine sources, apply filters, add attributes, and create hierarchies.
They produce complete lists of individual values without aggregation, even for numeric fields.
The text explains that querying a dimension view returns every individual value and does not aggregate, including numeric values.
They are primarily used to compute and present measures with aggregation.
The text contrasts this with cube calculation views; dimensions do not aggregate measures.
They are not reusable and should be duplicated for each cube calculation view.
The text emphasizes they are reusable and shared across multiple cube views.
They cannot be consumed by cube calculation views.
The text explicitly notes that dimension calculation views will be consumed in cube calculation views.
Differentiate attribute-focused models from measure-aggregating models.
Recall whether dimensions are shared across multiple cubes.
Think DIM: Details, Integration, and Metadata—details unaggregated, integrate sources, enrich with attributes/hierarchies.

Dimension views expose master data with attributes, filters, calculations, and hierarchies, return non-aggregated records, and are reusable and consumed by cube views. Aggregated measures belong to cube views.
Describe a scenario where one product dimension feeds multiple cubes and why non-aggregated detail is beneficial.
A Product dimension is created once and reused in both Purchase Order and Sales Order cube calculation views for consistent product attributes.
Which scenario best fits using a dimension calculation view rather than a cube calculation view?

Dimension calculation views expose master data, allow combining sources, filters, calculated attributes, and hierarchies, and are commonly reused by multiple cube views. They output individual values without aggregation.
Providing a reusable product master with attributes and hierarchies for both sales and purchasing analytics.
Matches the purpose: expose master data, add attributes/hierarchies, and reuse across multiple cube views.
Computing total quantities by product with sums and time-period aggregations.
Aggregations like sums belong to cube calculation views, not dimension views.
Building a KPI that calculates revenue variance vs. target using measures.
KPI measures and aggregations indicate a cube use case, not a dimension view.
Creating a transactional fact table that pre-aggregates order items by day.
Pre-aggregation and transactional facts align with cube calculation views.
Summarizing numeric attributes into a single record per product category.
Summarization is aggregation; dimension views list individual values without aggregation.
Ask: Is the goal to expose master data with attributes and hierarchies, or to aggregate measures?
Dimension views produce non-aggregated individual values; cubes handle sums.
DIM = Describe Items of Master data; CUBE = Calculate Using Business aggregates.
A dimension calculation view is for master data exposure with attributes/hierarchies and is reusable by multiple cubes. Aggregations and measures belong to cube calculation views.
Identify which choice mentions reuse across multiple analytical contexts without aggregations.
A product dimension view feeds both a sales order cube and a purchase order cube with consistent product attributes.
The statement below is accurate according to the text.
Dimension calculation views expose master data, allow combining sources and defining attributes, and are commonly reused by multiple cube calculation views.
True
False
Check whether dimensions aggregate measures by default.
Recall which type is used when you need sums: cube or dimension?
Dim = details; Cube = compute (aggregations).
False. The text explains that a dimension calculation view lists individual values and does not aggregate; summing requires a cube calculation view.
Rewrite the statement to correctly reflect how aggregation is handled in dimension vs. cube views.
A product dimension lists each product row; totals like quantity sums are produced in a cube that consumes the dimension.
Select all statements that correctly describe dimension calculation views and their use cases.

Dimension calculation views expose master data, can combine sources, apply filters, compute attributes, and define hierarchies. They list individual values rather than aggregated measures and are commonly reused by multiple cube calculation views.
They expose master data and can include calculated attributes and hierarchies.
The text states they expose master data and allow calculating attributes and creating hierarchies.
They produce a complete list of individual values rather than aggregated measures when queried.
The text explains that outputs are individual values; aggregation like summing requires a cube view.
They are primarily designed to compute totals and sums across numeric fields.
Aggregation is associated with cube calculation views, not dimensions.
They cannot be reused across different cube calculation views.
The text emphasizes reusability across several cube views, e.g., purchase and sales order cubes.
They are intended to store transactional measures alongside master data.
The text positions dimension views for master data and not for measures; measures belong in cubes.
Differentiate master data exposure from transactional aggregation.
Recall which view type is reused by multiple cube views.
DIM = Describe Items (master data) and Metadata; CUBE = Crunch numbers (aggregations).

A and B align with the description: dimension views expose master data, allow calculations and hierarchies, and output individual values. C confuses dimensions with cubes. D contradicts the sharing/reusability note. E misattributes measures to dimensions.
Explain why a product dimension can serve both purchase order and sales order cubes.
A Product dimension combines product tables, adds a category attribute, defines a product hierarchy, and is consumed by both Sales Order and Purchase Order cube views.
Which statement best describes when to use a dimension calculation view rather than a cube calculation view?

The lesson explains that dimension calculation views expose master data, allow combining sources, filtering, calculating attributes, and building hierarchies, and are commonly reused across multiple cubes.
When you need to present master data attributes without aggregating measures.
The text states a dimension view exposes master data and outputs individual values, not aggregated measures.
When your main goal is to sum quantities and calculate totals.
Summations require a cube calculation view according to the text.
When you need transactional fact tables with measure aggregation.
Transactional facts with aggregation align with cube calculation views, not dimension views.
When you want to hide master data so it cannot be shared across models.
The text says dimension views are reusable and shared, not hidden.
When you need to pre-aggregate numerical attributes before consumption by cubes.
Dimension views list values individually; pre-aggregation is not their purpose.
Recall whether dimension views aggregate or list values individually.
Think about master data versus measures when choosing the view type.
Dimension = Details of master data; Cube = Calculations on measures.

Dimension calculation views serve master data use cases with attributes, filters, and hierarchies, producing non-aggregated outputs and intended for reuse by cubes. Aggregations and totals are responsibilities of cube calculation views.
Describe a scenario where a product dimension is reused by multiple cubes and explain why a cube is needed for totals.
A product master dimension is joined to purchase order and sales order cubes, which then aggregate quantities per product.
The statement below is accurate according to the text.
Dimension calculation views expose master data, can combine sources and attributes, and are reusable across multiple cube calculation views.
True
False
Check whether dimension views aggregate measures by default.
Recall which view type is used when you need to sum or aggregate values.
Dimension = Details; Cube = Calculations.
False. The text states that dimension calculation views list individual values (including numerics) without aggregation; summing requires a cube calculation view.
Rewrite the statement to correctly describe where aggregation occurs.
A product dimension view lists each product and its attributes; a sales cube view would aggregate quantities by product.
Select all statements that align with creating a cube calculation view and managing attributes/measures in a star join scenario.

Cube calculation views include measures and can pull columns from multiple tables. A CUBE with Star Join can bring in additional attributes from dimension calculation views, while handling shared column naming via aliases when needed.
A cube calculation view is the type to use when your model needs measures.
The text states that when you want a calculation view that includes measures, you use a calculation view of type: cube.
A CUBE with Star Join can enrich a sales cube with many product-related attributes by joining a product dimension.
The text explains you can join a product dimension calculation view to provide many more product-related attributes in a star join calculation view.
Shared columns coming from joined dimensions can have their Name and Label directly changed in the cube.
The text says their Name and Label properties cannot be changed; you can define Alias Name and Alias Label instead.
Alias names may be required to resolve conflicts between column names from dimensions and private columns.
The text notes providing Alias Names is mandatory if column names conflict between dimension views or with private columns.
Once attributes are brought in via a star join, they cannot be hidden from the final output.
The text indicates you can hide some of these columns to keep only those you need.
Recall which calculation view type is explicitly associated with measures.
Think about how name conflicts are handled for columns from dimension views.
Cube = measures; Star Join = add attributes; Conflicts = aliases.

Cubes are for measures (A). Star joins add attributes from dimensions (B). Shared column names require aliases when there are conflicts (D). You cannot change Name/Label directly on shared columns (contradicting C), and attributes can be hidden (contradicting E).
Identify a scenario where aliasing prevents a conflict between a dimension’s column and a private column.
A sales cube pulls Quantity Sold from Sales and Quantity Returned from Returns, then joins a Product dimension to add product description and color, aliasing duplicate ‘ProductID’ names as needed.
In the context of creating a CUBE calculation view, what is the primary purpose of using a Star Join?

A cube calculation view includes measures and can combine facts with additional attributes. Shared columns from joined dimensions have fixed Name/Label, but Alias Name/Label can be defined to resolve conflicts.
To enrich the cube’s measures with additional attributes by joining related dimension calculation views.
The text states that a star join lets a cube with measures gain many more related attributes by joining dimension calculation views.
To change the default aggregation behavior of all measures within the cube.
The passage does not say the star join alters measure aggregation behavior.
To allow renaming of shared column Name and Label properties directly in the cube.
It explicitly notes shared columns’ Name/Label cannot be changed; only aliases can be defined.
To source measures from dimension calculation views instead of fact tables.
The star join is described as adding attributes from dimensions, not sourcing measures from them.
To hide all columns by default and selectively unhide required ones.
The text mentions you can hide some columns, not that all are hidden by default via the star join.
Focus on how attributes from dimensions are brought into a cube with measures.
Remember the distinction between changing shared column names vs. assigning aliases.
Star = center facts with surrounding dimensions adding attributes.
A CUBE with Star Join connects a fact-like cube to dimension calculation views to add many more related attributes while measures remain in the cube.
